title: Yes, Meghan Markle should be considered a ‘working mom’ — but she’s not struggling the same way
text:
If there’s one thing that both blue blood and blue-collar moms can agree on, it’s that juggling work and kids can be a royal pain.

Still, Meghan Markle raised plenty of parents’ eyebrows this week after she offered some insight into her own work-life balance struggles during an event in Cape Town, South Africa.

The Duchess of Sussex, who gave birth to baby Archie with the Duke (aka Prince Harry) in April, told a room full of female entrepreneurs on Wednesday that, “Being a working mum and traveling as well with a baby, my goodness it’s a lot, but it’s all so exciting,” HuffPost reported.

She added, “There are days when it’s a lot to juggle, but then you meet someone and you have an impact on them, and you say ‘ah-ha,’ and it’s so rewarding.”

Some people took issue with Markle, 38, calling herself a “working” mother, however. After all, she left her paying gigs to marry into the House of Windsor last year, shutting down her lifestyle site The Tig and leaving the USA Network’s “Suits” after acting on the show for seven years.

Read more: What Meghan Markle is giving up to marry Prince Harry

“The royals do work hard but it isn’t like they’re stacking shelves or anything,” tweeted one HuffPost reader, ”and risk losing their jobs if they have to leave early to look after a sick child and they can afford excellent child care.”

“But you have servants and unlimited money!!” Posted another. “It’s no sweat compared to everyone else.”

If you need a good laugh -- Meghan Markle called herself a working mom... — ♡♡ (@aaachristiine) September 26, 2019

Did Meghan Markle really describe herself as a “working mum”? That’s mental. And suggesting it’s difficult is absolutely right, for actual working mums! — Mike Harris (@mikeharrisbsc) September 25, 2019

Indeed, Markle is fortunate enough to be free from two of the biggest struggles most working mothers face: finding affordable child care and paid leave.

Only 17% of civilian workers, and 16% of private industry workers, have access to paid family leave such as maternity leave, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And once the baby comes, only 15% of private sector workers get paid leave for things like sick days, which leaves most parents struggling to arrange child care if their kids fall ill.

What’s more, child-care costs have jumped to almost $10,000 a year for just one child’s day care. Almost 2 million parents with kids under five had to quit their job, refuse an offer or switch jobs in 2016 because of child-care issues. And about one-third of mothers in a recent FlexJobs survey said that having kids threw their careers off track, because their jobs were too inflexible for them to work and raise kids. And 70% of those women who left the workforce to raise children have had difficulty coming back.

Read more: 7 in 10 parents admit to sending sick kids to school, but they have 3 good reasons why

And that doesn’t even get into the financial and child-care issues faced by single moms, considering about one in four U.S. mothers are raising their children on their own — including Markle’s own mother, Doria Raglan, once upon a time. Women already earn just 80 cents for every dollar a man makes, on average, with black women making just 61 cents for every dollar earned by white men, and Latina women earning 53 cents. And single mothers are statistically almost five times more likely to be poor than married-couple families. (That’s not stopping single moms from raising kick-ass kids, however.)

Lauren Pullar, a mother of two from Long Island, sympathized with Markle’s working mom guilt — with some caveats. “Regardless of your job, there is always a feeling of guilt that you’re missing out on something,” said Pullar, 41. “However … her experience of motherhood is far different from mine. Having an army of nannies, and staff at beck and call, makes the ‘struggles’ of working a lot easier.”

Getty Images How relatable are the royals?

But Meredith Bodgas, editor in chief of Working Mother and a mother of two, told MarketWatch that Markle is, in fact, probably experiencing many of the same learning curves and emotional struggles as new parents everywhere.

Related: Child-care costs forced this single mom to give up her job

And yes, she considers both Markle and fellow duchess and sister-in-law Kate Middleton working moms.

“They are out and about for long hours, the way working mothers are. And I will not pretend that they have it just as hard as we have it; they don’t, it’s much easier. But they are working, and I don’t consider them to be stay-at-home moms,” said Bodgas.

“Yes, their lives are probably much better and much easier, much richer, than the average working mother’s life. They have the best nannies in the world. They have every comfort that they could possibly want,” she added. “But they still have royal duties which take them away from their children. They still have royal duties that take them places that they might not necessarily want to go.” And while the royals technically don’t have to worry about being fired, per se, “there probably are repercussions that we don’t know about,” said Bodgas.

Denise Albert, a mother of two and co-founder of TheMOMS.com and Mamarazzi, agreed.

“Meghan is a working mom. It’s obviously different for her than the rest of the moms in the world, but any woman, regardless of their status and lifestyle, goes through many of the same struggles internally when trying to find a way to do their ‘all’,” she said. “I 100% believe she does struggle, and though she’s a duchess and might look like she lives in a fairy tale, at the beginning and end of every day, she is a new mom adjusting and learning how to be the best mom to Archie, while working and doing it all in the public eye.”
description: Mothers are divided on the Duchess’ remarks that being a working mom is “a lot.”
